Award.AwardTitle: Support for the Fourteenth Workshop on the Economics of Information Security (WEIS 2015)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides support for the 2015 Workshop on the Economics of Information Security (WEIS). WEIS fosters cross-disciplinary, cross-sector (i.e., academia, industry, nonprofit, and government), and cross-national discussion on information security. The focus on the economics of information security was chosen not only because of its intrinsic importance, but also because of its basis for bringing together social, computer, and information scientists and engineers to share knowledge, information and methods from their respective domains. WEIS covers issues that are core to the NSF's Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program, and spans both the Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE) Directorates within the Foundation.

The WEIS conference draws a 50/50 split between US and European participants, with a small number of participants from Asia. The venue rotates between US and European locations, with two years in the US for every year in Europe.

All funds from this grant will go towards supporting US undergraduate and graduate student attendance at the WEIS conference, to be held in June 2015 at the Delft University of Technology in The Netherlands. This project will thus provide US students with valuable opportunities for students to meet and interact with notable researchers, thereby furthering their own research careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award provided travel support for students to attend the Workshop on the Economics of Information Security (WEIS) held at Delft University of Technology, in Delft, the Netherlands, on June 22-23, 2015. WEIS is widely recognized as a leading forum for interdisciplinary scholarship on information security and privacy, combining expertise from the fields of economics, social science, business, law, policy, and computer science.

 This award allowed eight U.S.-based graduate students to attend the workshop. Awards were made to two women and six men; seven were Ph.D. students in various technical fields and one was a Ph.D. student in economics. Five students were also presenters at the workshop. The awardees came from the following academic institutions:

University of Texas at Austin

University of New Mexico Albuquerque

Princeton University

Southern Methodist University

University of Michigan

Polytechnic School of Engineering of NYU

 Students’ participation in prestigious academic events such as WEIS is a critical part of their educational experiences by providing them the opportunity to interact with senior researchers and other junior colleagues, and to be exposed to leading-edge work in this interdisciplinary field with growing importance. Students were invited to apply for the travel funds through an announcement on the workshop website as well as broadcasts on relevant email lists, and were selected after a careful review process of their submitted materials.
